ES - 5.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Over the past five years there have been no large or small releases which have resulted in injuries, property damage or offsite consequences. An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed.


ES - 6.0 THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Riverbank Terminal maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The procedures describe the manner of response to a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs. Employees receive training in emergency procedures. The overall emergency procedure program for the Riverbank Terminal is coordinated with the Stanislaus County Emergency Management Program. This coordination involves periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives. The Riverbank Terminal has around the clock communications capability with appropriate Emergency Management Program officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., Stanislaus Consolidated Fire District). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. 

The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The emergency response program is updated, when necessary, based on modifications made to the plant facilities.


ES - 7.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW: 
The Riverbank Terminal conducts a pre-startup safety review prior to the operating equipment or systems following a modification that requires a change in process safety information. The purpose of the pre-startup safety review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment in service.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS: 
Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Plant operations and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to operations or facility management for resolution. 

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION: 
The Riverbank Terminal has procedures in place that require prompt investigation of incidents that resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in, a fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendation(s) to prevent a recurrence and forwards these results to the business management team for resolution.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION: 
The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Facility has implemented procedures regarding employee participation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. Kiva includes terminal operators in the Process Hazards Analyses and in the development of operating procedures. 

HOT WORK PERMIT: 
Regarding hot work that may occur on or near the LPG process, the Riverbank Terminal has developed a written contractor evaluation program and a Hot Work Permit program to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements. TRAINING: 
The Riverbank Terminal facility staff, and Kiva Energy corporate staff, understand that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program.
The training program is comprised of the following:
~ Initial employee training;
~ Periodic refresher training (provided at least every three years);
~ Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification;
~ Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training; and
~ Training records for each employee.

MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES & MECHANICAL INTEGRITY: 
The maintenance program at the Riverbank Terminal is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The Riverbank Terminal has established practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment. The basic aspects of this program include 
(1) training, 
(2) developing written procedures, 
(3) performing inspections and tests, 
(4) correcting equipment deficiencies. 

In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. Equipment inspections are conducted on a monthly or quarterly basis. The frequency of the inspection is based upon regulatory framework impacting the particular system or subsystem.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE: 
The Kiva Energy Riverbank Terminal employs a change management system that requires changes to various systems or items, such as process equipment, technology, procedures and other facility functions, be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. ES - 3.0 THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes. The detailed results of the evaluation are provided in the Risk Management Plan (RMP). Administrative controls limit the tank fill capacity to in accordance with NFPA 58 7.4.3.2(B).

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO. 
The worst-case release scenario is the release of LPG from a bank of four (4) storage tanks when at capacity. The scenario assumes a complete release of 430,440 pounds of LPG gas. The pressure wave (with an endpoint of 1 pound per square inch gauge over atmospheric pressure) would extend 0.6 miles (1 kilometers).

The pressure wave could reach the residential neighborhood located to the northwest of the site as well as the church and playing fields located to the south-southwest. The pressure wave has the potential to impact as many as 1105 residents. There are no sensitive receptors, environmental or otherwise, within this zone. 

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO. 
The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a catastrophic release from a full-sized (10,600-gallon water capacity), transport truck. VAPOR COMPRESSORS
Kiva uses vapor compressors to create a pressure differential between the tank cars or trucks being unloaded and the receiving vessels. The differential pressure pushes the LPG from the tank cars or trucks into the storage vessels. Kiva has two compressors to perform this function. A single compressor is used during offloading operations.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ES - 1.0 FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY
The owners, management, and employees of Kiva Energy - LP Terminal, LLC Riverbank (Riverbank Terminal) located at 5300 Claus Rd, Riverbank, California in Stanislaus County, are committed to the prevention of accidental release of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG, typically 40%-99% propane). If an accidental release should occur, the facility staff are prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate a release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Consolidated Emergency Response / Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.


ES - 2.0 FACILITY INFORMATION
The Riverbank Propane terminal facility is a bulk hydrocarbon storage and handling facility. The facility receives odorized and un-odorized propane LPG by rail car. The liquefied petroleum gas is stored in the facility's 16 aboveground, pressurized storage tanks prior to being loaded into DOT approved delivery trucks (including those owned by Kiva Energy as well as third-party distributors).

Kiva Energy uses propane vapor compressors to offload the contents of the rail cars spotted on the facility rail siding. The same compressors are subsequently used to remove vapors from the empty cars prior to their disconnection from the tank fill piping and railcar unloading racks. Kiva Energy can receive non-odorized propane at this location. Kiva Energy adds ethyl mercaptan to the propane as the liquefied, compressed gas is conveyed to the storage tanks. Odorized propane is not dosed with additional odorant.
